Fields.DialogueText: Belfast?
Did they say anything? The admirals?
The operation...
Operation Tot.

Fields.MenuText: We're not calling it "Operation Tot."
Not my call, I'm afraid.
Fine, Operation Tot.

Fields.DialogueText: We'll discuss it later.
Well, that was the name I put in my proposal. I think they'll use it.
Yay!
Anyway, it's under review. I almost think certain members of the British government would rather we stick to the Mediterranean, but...
The Hebrides are very, very British. I can't imagine we won't get authorization to liberate what was taken.
There's one more thing, by the way.
Morganas. Closing in.
Well, them too.
@BATTLE
Well done, Belfast. That last one could've been tricky.
You standing there being inspirational made all the difference.
I don't know if you knew, but I took classes in standing inspirationally at the naval college. If the instructors could see me now!
Ha! I'll bet you were teaching the class by the end.
Anyway, the other news. The admirals tell me we're having a guest.
Again.
Joanna?
Yes.
Well, that's... odd. I mean, I'm happy, but...
Yeah. Well, I'm sure there's a compelling explanation, but I haven't heard it yet.
At least it's probably harmless.
I will remind you you said that when it all goes to hell. Just so you know.
At least Scapa Flow is a little bit more convenient for picking up passengers than Belfast.
Lots of Morganas.
I know. We really need to burn out the infection in the Hebrides.
And the Faroes.
And the Faroes.
We need Operation Tot.
You really are planning to just repeat the name over and over again until everyone starts using it, aren't you?
Operation. Tot.
You know in German that's "Operation Dead," right?
Don't be so negative. Would you like to sink some Morganas so we can get to port?
Oh, let's.
@BATTLE
Good job, everybody. Belfast, any injuries we need to take care of?
I don't think any crewmen came away with worse than a sprain, Captain. I'll be paying attention, though.

Fields.MenuText: Thank you.
How about you?
Good. Can I interest you in about a gallon of coffee before Miss Sheridan arrives?

Fields.DialogueText: All part of the service.
Oh, I'm fine. I like to think a bit of scratched paint makes a girl more interesting.
Yes. Yes, yes, yes. Can I have your sugar, too?
Sugar in the fuel tank? You sure?
Quiet, you.
I'll be sure to get us into more scrapes.
Captain?
Hmm?
I know the timing isn't ideal, but I told Joanna you might be available to talk for a minute or two.

Fields.MenuText: Belfast, we really are in Morgana-infested waters here...
Has she said anything about what she's doing here? I assume it's not another paper.
Sure, send her up.

Fields.DialogueText: Trust me, I know. But she's been nervous ever since she got on board. I think it's important.
She said she wanted to settle in first. I think she's scared, though.
Will do.
Miss Sheridan? Good to see you again.
Likewise. And, please, Captain, call me Joanna.
So... do you have a particularly moving homily for me, or...?
I've been getting letters from a Morgana. Belfast is down in my quarters reading them now, I think.
Letters. Delivered to your door letters?
Yes. With postage, no less.
... You'll forgive me if I require some convincing.
Captain? I've looked them over.
I'm pretty sure they're written in human blood. I have... well, sometimes my senses are too good for my own good.

Fields.MenuText: Are you okay, Belfast?
Well. Just when I'd thought they had run out of ways to make me want to shoot them.
And what do these letters say, exactly?

Fields.DialogueText: Well, no. Thank you. But I'm not the one with the problem here.
Oh, they're very creative about things like that.
Joanna?
When I was here last time, I... well, in a fit of silliness, I threw them a message in a bottle.
Just saying that I was a divinity student, and that I wanted to know if they were demons. I said I had questions for them if they were.
I was... it wasn't serious.
But apparently they collect our refuse. Anything that goes over the side of the ship, if they find it, they try to use it.
Dammit. I want new security procedures in place immediately. Anything that can be burned...
It's not like we've been throwing intelligence overboard.
Are you sure? I mean, think about it. We still don't know what these things can...
Captain, this might not be the best time. Morganas incoming.
Right. Miss Sheridan, I'm going to want to see those letters. I assume someone in the British government already has?
Not exactly.
Wonderful. Get somewhere safe. We'll talk later.
At least you have something to shoot...
@BATTLE
We're clear, Captain.
Good.
So what do they want? What are those letters about?
The Morgana claims to want a meeting.
Really.
It's the one called Treason. Just in case you're looking for a theme.
It really is so much easier when we just see them and sink them.
Oh, that's just grand.
How're we doing?
I think they know we're here.

Fields.MenuText: For all the good it does them.
Have an appropriate verse at hand?
You sound... strangely pleased.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm ready when you are, Captain.
Oh... hm. How about Isaiah 8:10? "Devise your strategy, but it will be thwarted; propose your plan, but it will not stand..."
It's not that strange, is it? I just like blowing these monsters up.
Stations, everyone!
@BATTLE
Good job, everyone.
I'm not sure this is exactly what the powers that be meant by "reconnaissance." I'm not complaining, but...
We're documenting Morgana movements between the Hebrides, Shetland, and the Faroe Islands. Nobody said we had to be quiet about it.
It's interesting, though. They really don't seem to be coordinating with the Morganas on the Norwegian coast.
Yeah. They're just off doing their own things.
You think it could be Treason?
I don't know that I care. If so, she's probably trying to trick us into something. We don't need the distraction.
You've read the letters?
Yeah. They don't make Joanna look particularly good.
I know. But she did bring them to us.
I never said she was completely out of her mind.
"...For God is with us." Let's hope you're right.
Perhaps I'm an angel after all, then?
Wake me up going "be not afraid" and I'll convert you into a mail ship.
Captain? You wanted to see me?
Yes.
You've read the letters.
Oh, yes. And they certainly seem to suggest that you talked to Treason in person. Did I read that wrong?
Not exactly. You saw that I was supposed to go to certain places at certain times?
Which was very stupid.
Well, honestly, the three of us only met because I talked my way onto a magic warship in the middle of ongoing hostilities because I wanted to talk about angels.
Surprise! I don't have good sense!

Fields.MenuText: Legitimate point.
Let's get back to these meetings.
Well, I guess we all have at least one thing in common.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't encourage her.
Please.
"If a blind man leads a blind man, both will fall into a pit." Don't make me dig you one.
I was always sent to deserted shorelines after dark. I never saw anyone, or even a ship in the water. I was just supposed to call out, and I think she always heard me.
Written responses would come within four or five days.
I told my godfather, the admiral, that... well, that I'd received information from you that those stretches of the coast might have a Morgana presence.
It's not like I wanted to leave anything undefended. I mean, this was close to home!
But nobody ever spotted anything.
Well, that's something.
Right. I'm pretty sure you're not in any trouble, but you really should have turned this stuff over to someone on land.
They wouldn't have let me come out here. You saw the invitation part, right?
We're not turning you over to a Morgana. I don't care what she's offering.
You saw what she did to the dolphins!
But...
It's a trap. It's not like it would give you your interview and let you go. You have to know that.
I was actually thinking I should... I mean, you could give me a bomb or something.
I've thought about it, and if there's something I can do for the war effort, I...
No.
Yeah, that's the Belle Veto. It's a thing.
But if you take me to the place where... I mean, you'll at least know where she'll be, right?
No, we won't, because – again – it's obviously a trap.
It's not as though we're having a hard time finding Morganas anyway, Joanna.
The ones you were looking for?
Yes. We have an intercept course.
Then that's it for now, Miss Sheridan.
I just want to help.
We already have a plan. I can't talk about it, but we call it Operation Tot.
Command hasn't actually authorized the name yet.
@BATTLE
Hush. You'll spoil my aim.
That one's Draco.
For dragon?
Yes, indeed. I do believe that particular one guarded the golden apples of immortality. The Greek ones, not the Norse ones.
Hercules killed it, I think. Possibly after a torrid sexual affair. Greek mythology is strange like that.
I know the constellations to navigate by. I didn't know the stories.
To be fair, I'm making at least half of them up.
Trawling the coast of Orkney after thirty-six straight hours of scouting inspires a certain poetic exuberance.
Not the ones about Constellations Groucho and Harpo, please.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not so much making those up as anticipating the decisions of future generations. I'm sure by 1960 someone will have made it official.
Well, they're the stars I navigate by, at least.
It's remotely possible I might have indulged my creative instincts there, yes. A bit.

Fields.DialogueText: Who gets to decide that kind of thing? Is there a special panel of mad captains of living warships?
That explains a lot.
I think I'm going to choose to believe it anyway.
We should do this more often. I mean, we're out here all the time. It's a sailor's duty to look up at the sky and tell stories.
I absolutely agree.
The Morganas are almost in range, though. What do the stars say about them?
Why, I just saw one explode. Let's take that as a fair omen.
@BATTLE
Good job, everyone. Belfast, can I have a minute?
Captain? You look... a little bit more malevolent than usual.
Did we get orders we don't like before the battle? You didn't say.
Stage one of the operation has been authorized. In a few days we head for the Faroe Islands, and roll back the Morgana colonies that came from the Hebrides.

Fields.MenuText: And, yes, they're calling it Operation Tot.
Air support will be limited, but that's not exactly a surprise.
That's the good news.

Fields.DialogueText: My work here is done!
We didn't really ask for much, anyway. If we come in when the Morganas are light in the water, we'll be fine.
I suppose it's too much to hope that the bad news is an embarrassing press event for Bulldog?
It's just... something feels off about this, and I don't know what.
Okay. Talk me through it.
Well, some of it is that... okay, we think this group of Morganas is allied with Treason, right?
Assuming what Joanna brought us isn't just disinformation. You're the one who keeps saying we shouldn't do that.
True.
But, set that aside for a second. Part of why we're targeting the Faroe Islands is to draw Morgana activity away from Britain and Norway.
What if most of the Morganas don't care, though? What if they're meant to be compartmentalized?
The strategic value of the action may be a whole lot less than we thought when we proposed the op.
Okay, but, counterpoint -
We really, really want Lewis and North Uist to be Morgana-free.
So we do. We've got time. Let's use it.
@BATTLE
No such thing, I'm afraid.
Um... Captain? Is this a good time?
We're approaching a vileness of Morganas, Joanna. Maybe later.
I still don't know that "vileness" works as a group name. It's descriptive, but not active.
Well, crows already have "murder." A malaise of Morganas?
An outrage of Morganas? An atrocity of Morganas.
Ooh. A festering of Morganas!
How about ruination?
A ruination of Morganas. Hm. Let me think about that. That might be good.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe if we spit in disgust every time we say it.

Fields.DialogueText: YES!
I do believe we're trailblazers.
... I'll just go back to my quarters.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Isn't there already one called Ruin?

Fields.DialogueText: Synonyms, Captain. We've got a whole dictionary of possibilities.

Fields.MenuText: Who do we submit this to?

Fields.DialogueText: Just Operation Tot it, Captain. Eventually it'll catch on.
Found my range, Captain! Firing for effect!
@BATTLE
All clear. And, Captain...
Wait. Wait. Before any other business distracts us. That battle was almost... quieter. Did you notice?
Heck, if I didn't know it was impossible, I'd say the guns are even getting less deafening.
Oh. Well, yeah, I've been trying... they're kind of like breathing exercises, I suppose. Are they helping?
Yeah. I mean, if it's a distraction, you really don't need to, but...
No! No, I'm happy to help. I don't want anybody coming out of this war with ringing ears if I can help it.
Very decent of you. The whole crew appreciates it.
Awww.
Oh, right. Joanna's here.
You wanted to talk to me, Captain?
Oh, yes. We thought we owed you an explanation.
For not... sorry, you say it.
For not taking you back to Scapa Flow. We're going to be very active soon, and past experience suggests that some of the Morganas hold grudges.
And since they know you by name...
Exactly. It's for your own safety.
What my ship said.
You're doing it again.
Doing what?
You're looking at Belfast a little too long. And she smiles and you smile wider and she looks away, but...

Fields.MenuText: You're imagining things.
What? No. No! She's just got something in her teeth.
It is pretty obvious, isn't it?

Fields.DialogueText: The Captain's just trying to stay on my good side so the bridge stays quiet in combat.
I don't! Do I?
I think the Captain's just been hit on the head one too many times.
I honestly can't tell if this is adorable or disturbing.
Suðuroy ought to be visible at any time, Captain.
Operation Tot is officially a go, then. Remember, keep your eyes open for salvage. January Abbott will chew my head off if we don't bring her new toys.
It's funny you should say that. Rumour on the Belle circuit is that she wants to dissect your brain to see if there's a physiological reason we all pay attention to you.

Fields.MenuText: Actually, that's true. But she's promised to wait until somebody else kills me. Fair enough, I guess.
My life is really very strange.
She thinks you all pay attention to me? HA!

Fields.DialogueText: Sometimes I forget how weird you are.
At least you're meeting interesting people. Not to mention stunning.
I was originally going to say "tolerate," now that you mention it.
Yeah, well...
Later. We have incoming.
@BATTLE
More incoming.
I see them.
I don't think there are even that many. It's just that there are one or two hiding in every single fjord in these godforsaken rocks.
I don't think "godforsaken" is quite the right...

Fields.MenuText: Consider it retracted.
Really? You really want to talk theology now?
Well, I would use filthier language, but you always complain.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you.
Not theology. I'm just sure the people who live here love the place dearly.
I just think that sailors cursing plays to unfortunate stereotypes.
All hands, brace yourselves for the Battle of...
Lambavik, I think.
Lambavik!
@BATTLE
Well, they're not shooting Morganas in the dark.
Quickly, now, before the captain falls asleep!
@BATTLE
All clear. But nobody relax quite yet.
Captain? Joanna's here to say hello...
Don't take this the wrong way, but you two look terrible. Have you slept at all since Operation Tot started?
I don't really need to sleep. The Captain, on the other hand...

Fields.MenuText: I'm fine, Bel. Really.
The Captain is sustained by white-hot malice and the terror of my enemies. Thanks for asking.
Huh? Whuh? FIRE AT MY MARK!

Fields.DialogueText: I wish we could get you more coffee before the shooting starts again.
You're sustained by gallons of coffee and disturbingly frequent bathroom trips.
There, there. You poor thing.
I'm okay.
You don't need to stay awake. Nobody's going to sink me while you nap.
We're not going to test that proposition.
I want to check the waters east of Fugloy again. No margin for sloppiness here.
I'm not that tired and you're not that quiet.
I'm trending better. You concern me. We'll discuss it later.
And there it is. Djupini Sound.
The nexus of the Faroe infection.
It looks... pretty horrible, doesn't it?

Fields.MenuText: We'll be clearing it out. Just focus on that.
We haven't seen much sign of human life on these islands, either. The Morganas have been busy.
After what they served at breakfast, I'm afraid my standards for "horrible" have shifted.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, believe me, it's very much on my mind.
There were evacuations, I think. I hope.
You really were a magnificent shade of green this morning.
We can't really hit the main fortifications until the Royal Marines have come in from the south.
I know. I literally helped write the plan.
I'm talking to myself.
We can keep them from fortifying further. We can break incoming reinforcements.
Like those over there.
Was that a suggestion?
You might even call it a request.
Well, you know me. I hate to say no to a good time.
@BATTLE
Captain? Any news on the Royal Marines?
They're getting the job done, but when you read the reports and factor in a certain degree of British understatement...
It's bad?
I think so. It also sounds like the Morganas are leaving traps and trying to take prisoners, and that's never good.
What if we attack the Morgana fortifications early? Would that take some pressure off the boys?

Fields.MenuText: Bel, are you suggesting we go off-plan? After all the work we put into it? I'm shocked!
That's what I'm thinking.
Maybe. But it would put more pressure on us, and we need to be able to mop up in the end.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm just saying that we should pursue an undocumented contingency operation.
Good. We can handle it.
We will be. I promise.
You're sure about this?
Yes.
Okay, then.
@BATTLE
Well, that was good work.
Captain, word from the radio room. Do we have room for wounded?
Most of them are people the Morganas... experimented on. Not Royal Marines, but Faroe Islanders.

Fields.MenuText: Of course. Make sure they're comfortable.
... Fine. But I want them under guard. They may not be in control of their actions.
I'd rather not risk it. Is there any medical infrastructure left on the islands? Can we check?

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, Captain.
Well, that's a depressing idea. Okay.
Um... when I asked if we had room for wounded, I probably should have made it clear that Command wants the answer to be "yes."
... I may need to use that line sometime.
Wonderful. Make sure they're under guard. I don't want any cuckoos in our nest.
Captain? Belfast? I've been trying to help out in the infirmary, and they...
I know. The Captain doesn't. But, this isn't a good time.
The Morganas seem to be giving up on the Faroe Islands, at least for now. The Royal Marines are making a push, and meeting just token resistance.
And the Morganas are mobilizing and disassembling their bases – it's all going back into the water.
Which is... good?
Mostly. But it's happening faster than we expected, and it's moving the conflict more toward us.
This probably won't be as bad as some of the fighting back around the Hebrides, but...
You think?
You don't?
They've had a fair amount of time to dig in here, Belfast. Could be a real mess.
So... I'll just go hide, then.
Probably wise.
@BATTLE
All clear for now. Good work, everyone. Catch a breath before they regroup.
Belfast? What was Joanna coming here to tell us about?
Ah. There's been some strange activity in the infirmary.
"Strange" as in the doctor's been drinking?
Strange as in all the Faroe Islanders who were too badly injured to move are awake. And in distress.
And some of them seem to be making synchronized movements.

Fields.MenuText: Right. Make sure they stay under observation. Armed observation.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, Captain.
Oh, and... by the way?
Captain?
Good job liberating the Faroe Islands, Belfast. Another fight or two like this and we'll see if we can get you a medal or something.

Fields.MenuText: It's dangerous to even have them aboard you.

Fields.DialogueText: I know what they're doing and where, Captain. I'll be the first to know if they are.

Fields.MenuText: To what end?

Fields.DialogueText: Nothing leather straps and sedatives can't sort out... poor dears.
Belfast? You okay?
Yes. But I'm listening to something.
Dolphins again?
The wounded Faroe Islanders. They're trying to talk to Joanna. She knows I can hear, so she's playing along.
Playing along with...?
Apparently, Treason is offering us some kind of deal.

Fields.MenuText: This should be good.
In exchange for letting her withdraw the rest of her forces from the Faroe Islands? Pass.
Treason told them this?

Fields.DialogueText: By which you mean terrible? Probably.
They haven't gotten that far yet.
I think Treason is telling them what to say now.
We should get Joanna out of there. Treason's shown too much interest in her already.
I should probably add that the Morganas approaching us now don't seem to be proposing a cease fire.
That's a shock.
@BATTLE
If that thing can communicate with them from distance, I want them even more sealed off than they already are.
You see them?
Mm-hm.
So, we're agreed - Treason seems to have given us the location of a Morgana convoy to the Norwegian coast, ostensibly as a sign of good faith.
Correct.

Fields.MenuText: Yeah, this is a trap.
I don't like the source, but I don't mind sinking Morganas.
What. The. Hell.

Fields.DialogueText: If so, it's the kind of trap we can shoot our way out of. You usually like those.
As long as you're happy, Cappy.
If you want to discuss the religious implications, I can call Joanna up.
Captain... you know she's angling to keep us from freeing the Hebrides. Or at least to slow us down. If the people in charge fall for this...
One thing at a time, Belfast. Sink what's in front of us.
@BATTLE
Well, that was unsatisfying.
So now we report back that Treason seems to be legitimately helping us against her fellow Morganas, and...?
She says she'll help Britain keep India and their Mediterranean assets if she gets to rent out the Hebrides a bit longer.
... I don't want to know.
... I will pay you cold hard cash to never call me that again.
Think they'll go for it?
Problems, Belfast?
@BATTLE
All clear. Well done, Belfast. Well done, crew.
Nobody get cocky.
So... what do you think?

Fields.MenuText: I think the Hebrides are more important than we realized before. I think Treason's stalling us while she builds something.
I think I'm lucky to be the captain of a fine ship.
I gave up thinking years ago. It kept getting me into trouble.

Fields.DialogueText: I've always admired your ability to really search silver linings until you find dark clouds.
... I am not displeased.
Oh? How is trouble-free life treating you, then?
Seriously. Treason.
I've hunted more of these things than any other human being alive.
One thing I'm pretty sure of is that however clever their plans are, they can't help themselves if you dangle bait in front of them.
So... what? We keep Treason from trying to win over world leaders by prodding her into doing something stupid?
I was going to say we illustrate vividly that she's never going to serve any needs but her own, but sure.
Well, Operation Tot is on hold until we get her to do the vivid illustrations, so I'm in.
What's the bait? What do we have that she wants enough to lose sight of her plans?
Yeah. Um... I'm still trying to think of something you won't hate.
I'm not thrilled to be running a Morgana's errands.
That makes two of us. Takes all the fun out of blasting the others.
Insult to bloody injury.
So we think Treason can hear everything our Faroe Islanders hear?
Yes.
Sort of. I can keep her from listening in, but I think she tries to kill them if I interfere too much. Seizures, arrhythmia, that kind of thing.
I'm blocking that too, but it's hard.
Have I mentioned that Abbott really, really, really wants us to deliver some brain tissue?
Ew.
I know!
And Treason controls them somehow? Their movements?
Yes. Unless I screen her out.
Okay. Okay, I think I have the beginnings of a really terrible plan.
We'll keep hitting the targets she's giving us for now, but let's start drifting toward the Hebrides when this is done.
I... yes, Captain. Are you going to tell us the really terrible plan?

Fields.MenuText: Oh, God, no. I don't want to hear the Belle's Veto speech again.

Fields.DialogueText: @BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: When the time is right. We can't risk this leaking.
I said the beginnings. Once I figure out the rest you'll be the first to know.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, do relax. I think of it as a weapon I hope I never use.
Now, really, Captain. We run a tighter ship than that.
Your creative process is incomplete without me.
Hold that thought. Seems we've got interlopers trying to listen in.
Hello, sir. Hello, Treason. I'm captain here.
Hssss?
I'm sorry we haven't met before.
Well, no. I'm not really sorry. Whatever's still human in you deserves better than this, and I hate playing along with your degradation.
Captain? You might not want to get too close...
No, see, I had an idea.
Treason, a good chunk of your Hebrides fleet is just about in shooting range now.
You're not shooting at us because you want my superior officers to start looking at you like you're an enemy human navy.
Awful, sure, but potentially an ally of convenience against the main Morgana fleet. Like how the Soviets put up with the Americans or the Brits stomach the Germans.
Fuuuh...
And, me, I've been told I shouldn't initiate combat with you as long as you're still supposedly trying to help us.
I could disobey orders, but... well, the alliances between all the human navies are kind of fragile, and there are a lot of people looking for an excuse to drum me out.
I could disobey orders and then lie, but Belfast wouldn't cover for me. Belles pretty much have to tell the truth if directly ordered to do so.
I suspect there's wiggle room, but...
Captain?
Sorry. Anyway, Treason, this is a scalpel.
Here, take it.
Captain, what are you...?
Hang on. We're getting to the interesting part.
This is a terrible idea.
Yeah, I told you that up-front.
Okay. So, Treason.
Your plan requires you to keep a cool head, pretend to be reasonable, and stall as long as possible.
But I don't think you can do it. Do you? I think, when push comes to shove, you're just too badly broken. Too crazy. Too...
YAAAARK!!!
Gah!

Fields.MenuText: Well, that stings.
Yeah, that's what I thought.
"Yaaark" to you too.

Fields.DialogueText: CAPTAIN! Are you...?
YOU IDIOT!
... I'm embarrassed for both of you.
I'm going to need bandages sent to the bridge. I suspect the Morganas are about to start shooting at us.
I don't... you... ARGH.
@BATTLE
... That could have gone better. Worse, too.
How's your arm?
It hurts.
Well, maybe next time you won't give the possessed zombie man a scalpel.

Fields.MenuText: Oh, sure, with the benefit of hindsight...
My options were limited, okay?
Hey. I'm the one in pain here!

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, look at me, I'm the drollest Captain in the fleet! Watch me do my droll dance!
Let me observe that one perfectly legitimate option was "don't let the evil ship's slave stab me."
... Please don't take the fun out of shouting at you, Captain.
Can we sink some Morganas now, please?
@BATTLE
Well done, everybody.
I don't know. Is it really a success if you don't get physically assaulted by a maniac?
Belfast, stop.
Operation Tot is a go. Our plan is underway. Okay?
This doesn't feel like a plan I had a hand in.
Captain, the bridge crew are all... uh... going out for a smoke.
I don't mind your terrible, stupid, dare-Treason-to-stab-me plan.
Well, that's good. I'm convinced.
I mind that you didn't tell me.
You would've blocked Treason's influence before the attack.
You... I'm a loyal vessel in your service and you're insinuating that I won't do my job.
... When you put it that way it almost sounds like I did something wrong.
Grr...

Fields.MenuText: Belfast, I knew I was going to get hurt, and it just wasn't something I wanted to think too much about before it happened. It was hard enough just doing it.
Belfast, whatever else I've done to annoy you, I would never even hint that you wouldn't do your duty. Never.
I'm sorry.

Fields.DialogueText: So, you're an idiot.
Thank you.
Just try to be less of a monkey's arse in the future, okay?
No promises.
... My droll dance looks nothing like that.
Don't tell me you never suspected.
I know.
Morganas almost in range, Captain.
Yep.
You know... Treason said she was going to take something from me, way back when.
Uh-huh.
And she knows that Joanna is my friend.
Apparently.
And she made a point of having all her puppets only talk to Joanna.
Yeah, I thought that was weird.
So, back when you were first talking about using bait to make Treason do something stupid, I almost thought...

Fields.MenuText: No. I wasn't going to put you in that position.

Fields.DialogueText: Okay.
Maybe we should start shooting at the Morganas now.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: She's our guest, not our bait.

Fields.DialogueText: At least your terrible ideas aren't horrible.

Fields.MenuText: I almost did too.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank God you didn't.
We'll consider it practice. Joanna's not the only thing she can take from me.
You've done a splendid job protecting the crew, Belfast.
... Them too...
You look strangely upbeat for a lady under constant attack.
This is better than I ever hoped! Treason is dismantling her operations in Lewis and North Uist all on her own!
Well, yes. So they can attack us in relentless waves.
I know! Maybe this really was worth you getting wounded!

Fields.MenuText: Plus I'm pretty sure the scar's going to be sexy and interesting.
Maybe just a bit less enthusiasm there?
And here I was, wondering what to get you for your birthday. Christening day. Whatever.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm sure the midshipmen's hearts will all be aflutter.
You're unhappy when I complain, you're unhappy when I'm excited – you're very hard to please, Captain.
I would also have been delighted with a nice scarf.
It's good to see you smile. Even if the reasons are insane.
Same to you, Captain.
@BATTLE
Hullo, Captain.
Miss Sheridan. How are things in the infirmary?
God knows. There's a pack of scientists arguing about how your captives can be safely transferred for further study.
I just needed some air.
I get that.
So, how's the war?
We've been doing okay. Got another messy one coming up, though. See them, off the to north?
Is that a lot? It seems like a lot.
Oh, if we'd been looking at that many in one place on day one of this mess, we'd pretty much all be dead now.
Today I like our odds.
To be fair, Belfast tells me you're a crazy person.

Fields.MenuText: Yeah? You... uh... talk about me a lot?
I think she means it affectionately.
Ahhh, she's a kidder.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, my God. You're just as bad as she says.
I think so too.
Uh-huh.
Have a good fight, Captain.
@BATTLE
Actually, I'm probably worse. She's very generous by nature.
You look...
Terrible?
Tired. You've never looked terrible a day in your life.
I'm pretty sure you've said otherwise on occasion.
You must have heard me wrong.
Word from the Royal Marines. North Uist is Morgana-free. Early signs from Lewis suggest the same.
Operation Tot is a success. Well done, you.
We do still have to fight the remnants of Treason's fleet, even if she's nowhere to be seen. And that thing she was building.

Fields.MenuText: Super-weapon?
Enh. Believe it or not, I have faith.
I didn't have anything else planned for today. You?

Fields.DialogueText: It's probably at least an adequate weapon. Maybe even better than average.
Believing in belief? That's getting kind of self-referential. Where does it end, Captain?
Cleaning the guns. Ugh. This is definitely better.
So... according to Joanna, now's the part where you smile and I smile wider and you look away.
I'm not looking away. I like looking at you.
Oh.
Okay. Good. What else do you like doing?
You want to start by blowing up some Morganas? One more big one for all the marbles?
Always.
Oh, we'll think of something, Captain. A few somethings.
